sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a dissolution reaction
message_1: Calculate the standard enthalpy change for the dissolution of 5g of sodium chloride in 100mL of water at 25°C, given that the molar enthalpy of dissolution of NaCl is -3.9 kJ/mol.
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the dissolution of 5g of sodium chloride in 100mL of water at 25°C, we first need to determine the number of moles of NaCl being dissolved.

The molar mass of NaCl is 58.44 g/mol (22.99 g/mol for Na + 35.45 g/mol for Cl).

Now, we can calculate the number of moles of NaCl:

moles of NaCl = mass / molar mass
moles of NaCl = 5g / 58.44 g/mol
moles of NaCl ≈ 0.0856 mol

Now that we have the number of moles of NaCl, we can use the molar enthalpy of dissolution to calculate the standard enthalpy change:

ΔH = moles of NaCl × molar enthalpy of dissolution
ΔH = 0.0856 mol × (-3.9 kJ/mol)
ΔH ≈ -0.333 kJ

The standard enthalpy change for the dissolution of 5g of sodium chloride in 100mL of water at 25°C is approximately -0.333 kJ.
